docs.title: TuffSeal
docs.text: A small, explicit and embeddable scripting language with a C-style syntax, implemented entirely in Luau

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
let x = 10;
print(x * 2) // semicolons are optional!

docs.title: Why TuffSeal?
docs.text:
• Easy to embed
  • Explicit semantics
  • Designed for learning and experimentation

docs.title: Key Characteristics
docs.text:
• Interpreted, AST-based execution
  • Dynamically typed
  • First-class arrays and dictionaries
  • Expression-based functions
  • Built-in package manager (PMS / PackMySeal)

docs.title: Status
docs.text: TuffSeal is under active development. Syntax and semantics may evolve.

docs.title: TuffSeal
docs.text:
Download the latest TuffSeal release from github: - https://github.com/TuffSeal/TuffSeal/releases

Extract the binary and add it to your PATH.

Verify installation:

tuffseal --version

Once TuffSeal is installed, you can run test code by running it from a .tfs file or from the REPL.

To launch the repl:

tuffseal --repl

Inside the repl you can directly execute code. For example:

print("Hello, world!");

To run TuffSeal code contained in a .tfs script:

tuffseal --run script_path.tfs

docs.title: PackMySeal (PMS)
docs.text: PMS is the official package manager for TuffSeal.

docs.title: Windows (x86_64)
docs.text:
Currently, precompiled binaries are only provided for Windows(x86_64). Download it from the TuffSeal releases page and add it to your PATH.

Verify:

pms --version

docs.title: Other Platforms
docs.text:
On Linux, macOS or non-x86_64 systems. PMS must be built locally:

./build_pms.sh

or on Windows:

build_pms.bat

NOTE: Python is required to build TuffSeal. PyInstaller and other dependencies will be installed automatically by the build script.

docs.title: Creating a Project
docs.text:
To initialize a new project, run the following commands:

pms init my-project
cd my-project

PMS will create a new folder called "my-project". Inside of the folder, you will see a file: main.tfs This is the main script inside your project.

To run your project, run:

tuffseal run main.tfs

docs.title: Attribute Helpers
docs.text:
let obj = {
    a: 5,
    b: 10
}

if (hasattr(obj, "a")) {
    let v = getattr(obj, "a");
    print(v); // 5
}

These helpers allow explicit attribute inspection and access.

docs.title: hasattr
docs.text:
let obj = {
    x: 10,
    y: 41
}

if (hasattr(obj, "x")) {
    print("attribute exists!");
}

hasattr checks if a dictionary contains a specificed key. If it does, it returns true, if not then it returns false.

docs.title: getattr
docs.text:
let obj = {
    x: 10,
    y: 41
}

if (hasattr(obj, "x")) {
    print(getattr(obj, "x"));
}

getattr returns the value inside of a dictionary associated with a specified key. If the value or key does not exist, it returns null.

docs.title: setattr
docs.text:
let obj = {
    x: 10
}

setattr(obj, "y", 41);
print(obj.y); // 41;
print(getattr("obj", "y")); // 41

setattr adds a new key to the dictionary and assigns a provided value to it.

docs.title: Comments
docs.text:
TuffSeal currently only support single-line comments

// This is a comment

Comments are ignored by the lexer.

Block comments will be added in a future update.

docs.title: Conditionals
docs.text:
const x = 5;

if (x == 5) {
    print("x is 5!");
} elseif (x == 10) {
    print("x is 10!");
} else {
    print("x is something else!");
}

docs.title: Numeric For Loop
docs.text:
// for (i = starting point, max value of i (value to stop at), increment(how much to increase i by every time))
for (i = 1, 5, 1) {
    print(i); // 1, 2, 3, 4, 5
}

docs.title: Dictionary Iteration
docs.text:
const dict = {
    a: 5,
    b: 10
};

for (key, value in dict) {
    print(key, value);
}

docs.title: Array Iteration
docs.text:
const arr = [1, 2, 3];

const _ip = ipairs(arr);
for (index, value in _ip)
{
    print(index, value);
}

docs.title: While Loop
docs.text:
while (condition) {
    // ...
}

// example:
while (true) {
    // loop forever
}

let a = 1;
while (a <= 5)
{
    a = a + 1;
    print(a);
}

docs.title: Functions
docs.text:
Functions are declared using fn. Functions can be let or const.

let fn add(a, b)
{
    a + b;
}

const fn sub(a, b)
{
    // const functions cannot be reassigned / hooked
    a - b;
}

fn mult(a, b)
{
    a * b;
}

If a function declare type(let/const) is not defined, it defaults to let.

NOTE: TuffSeal doesn't have return. The last expression is returned automatically.

docs.title: Methods & Self Calls
docs.text:
TuffSeal supports method-style calls using !.

fn setA(self) {
    setattr(self, "a", 5);
}

let obj = {
    a: 1,
    setA: setA
};

print(obj.a); // 1

obj.setA()!;

print(obj.a); // 5

The ! operator explictly passes self.

docs.title: Modules & Imports
docs.text:
Modules can be:

  • .tfs files
  • Folders containing module.tfs

docs.title: Importing modules
docs.text:
// example
let mathmod = loadmodule("./math_module")!;
print(mathmod.add(1, 2)); // 3

NOTE: loadmodule must allways be called with ! as it requires the self variable.

Loading .tfs files as modules:

let module = loadmodule("./module.tfs")!;
module.do_whatever();

In the loadmodule function, after the path to the module you can include loadargs

let mod = loadmodule("./module", "everything after the module path will be a loadarg!", 1, 2, 3)!;

docs.title: Creating modules
docs.text:
Example module structure:

test_module /
    module.tfs

When loadmodule is ran on the module folder, module.tfs is ran and returned automatically.

Example module code:

let fn add(a, b) {
    a + b;
}

let fn sub(a, b) {
    a - b;
}

let test_module = {
    add: add,
    sub: sub
};

test_module; // modules must always return something!

You can either save this as a .tfs file and load it appropriately to a .tfs file, or you could make a new folder, create a file called module.tfs and insert the code into the file.

You can download and upload modules in PMS.

docs.title: Data Types
docs.text: TuffSeal is dynamically typed.

docs.title: Primitive Types
docs.text:
let n = 42; // integer / number
let s = "hi!";  // string

docs.title: Arrays
docs.text:
let arr = [1, 2, 3, "four"];
print(arr[0]);

NOTE: Array indexing starts at 0. arr[0] would return "1" because the object with the index 0 inside the array is the number one.

docs.title: Dictionaries
docs.text:
let dict = {
    a: "Hello!",
    b: 5
}

print(dict.a);
print(dict["b"]);

docs.title: type() Builtin
docs.text:
TuffSeal provides a builtin function for detecting what type is a specific variable.

let arr = [1, 2, 3]; // array
print(type(arr)); // "array"

//--------------------------//
let dict = {
    a: 5,
    b: 10
}

print(type(dict)); // "dictionary"

docs.title: Possible Values
docs.text:
• "fn" (functions)
  • "int" (numbers / integers)
  • "str" (strings)
  • "bool" (booleans)
  • "array" (arrays)
  • "dictionary" (dictionaries)
  • "luau_external" (other)

NOTE: If a variable has a type that doesn't exist inside of TuffSeal, but exists in Luau, it will return luau_external

docs.title: Variables
docs.text:
There are 2 types of variables in TuffSeal. - let - const

Variables are declared using let or const.

For example:

let x = 5;
const y = 10;

docs.title: let
docs.text:
• Mutable
  • Can be reassigned
let x = 1;
x = 2;

docs.title: const
docs.text:
• Immutable
  • Cannot be reassigned
  • Constant arrays and dictionaries are deeply immutable

WARNING: Reassigning a const variable is a runtime error.

docs.title: Main Commands
docs.text:
pms init [project-name]
pms install [module-name] [project-name]
pms remove [module-name] [project-name]
pms upload [module-name] [version] [zip-file]
pms list [module-name]

docs.title: Account Commands
docs.text:
pms register [username] [password]
pms login [username] [password]
pms logout
pms whoami

NOTE: You do not need a PMS account to use the install, list, or remove options. A PMS account is only require for the upload option.

docs.title: Creating Projects
docs.text:
To create a new PMS project, use the commands:

pms init my-project
cd my-project

Replace my-project with the project name you want to create.

Inside my-project there will be main.tfs and a folder called Modules as well as pms_project.json.

main.tfs should contain the main code for your project.

The Modules folder will contain every module you install from PMS.

When you run:

pms install [module-name]

The downloaded module will be saved to Modules.

docs.title: Installing Modules
docs.text:
To install a PMS package, run the command:

pms install [package-name] [project-name]

This will automatically install the latest version of the specified package into your project.

If project-name is not provided, PMS will assume that the current folder is the target project to install the package to.

To list all available versions for a specified package, run the command:

pms list [package-name]

You can install a specific version of a package by running:

pms install package-name@version [project-name]

Once you've installed a package, you can use it in your main.tfs script by doing:

let module = loadmodule("./Modules/package-name")!;

module.do_whatever();

docs.title: Uploading Modules
docs.text:
NOTE: To upload PMS packages, must be logged into a PMS account!

Once you have written the code for your module, you can upload it to PMS. To do that, you first have to compress your project into a .zip archive.

NOTE: Make sure that main.tfs and other files are directly in the root of the .zip archive! The structure of the archive should look like:

module.zip /
    Modules /
        ...
    main.tfs

Once everything is properly packed, you can upload it to PMS.

To upload a package to PMS, run:

pms upload [package-name] [version] module.zip

Your package will be uploaded to PMS servers.

docs.title: Removing Modules
docs.text:
To remove a package from your project, run the command:

pms remove [package-name] [project]

If the project arg is not provided, PMS will assume the current directory is the target project to remove the package from.

docs.title: Creating a new account
docs.text:
To create a new PMS account, run the command:

pms register [username] [password]

If the account was created successfully, you can now log into your PMS account.

docs.title: Logging into an account
docs.text:
To log into a PMS account, run the command:

pms login [username] [password]

If the username and password was correct, you will successfully log into your PMS account. Your auth information will be saved on your device.

docs.title: Logging out of a PMS account
docs.text:
To log out of a PMS account, run the command:

pms logout

This will log you out of your pms account and delete the auth file saved on your device.

docs.title: Identifying current PMS account
docs.text:
To get the username of the current logged-in PMS account, run the command:

pms whoami

This will output your PMS account username.

docs.title: PackMySeal (PMS)
docs.text:
PMS is the official package manager for TuffSeal.

Modules are distrubuted as folders containing module.tfs.

docs.title: print
docs.text:
Usage:

print(...); -- ... :: str | any

print("hello, world!");
print("hello, ", "world!");

docs.title: warn
docs.text:
Usage:

warn(...); -- ... :: str | any

warn("this is a warning!");

docs.title: error
docs.text:
Usage:

error(msg: str, level: int)

error("error!");
error("error", 2);

docs.title: len
docs.text:
Usage:

len(obj: array | str)

print(len("abc")) // 3
print(len([1, 2, 3])) // 3

docs.title: ipairs
docs.text:
Usage:

ipairs(obj: array): dictionary(int, str)

let arr = [1, 2, 3];
let __iter = ipairs(arr);

for (k, v in __iter) {
    print(k, v);
}

docs.title: push
docs.text:
Usage:

push(array: array, value: any)

let arr = [6, 7, 4, 1];

push(arr, 3);

print(arr); // [6, 7, 4, 1, 3]

docs.title: pop
docs.text:
Usage:

pop(array: array)

let arr = [1, 2, 3];
pop(arr);
print(arr); // [1, 2]

docs.title: get
docs.text:
Usage:

get(array: array, index: int)

let arr = [1, 2, 3];

print(get(arr, 0)); // 1

docs.title: remove
docs.text:
Usage:

remove(array: array, index: int)

let arr = [1, 2, 3];

remove(arr, 0);
print(arr); // [2, 3];

docs.title: find
docs.text:
Usage:

find(array: array, value: any): int?

let arr = [1, 2, 3];

let idx = find(arr, 3);
print(arr);

docs.title: format
docs.text:
Usage:

format(base_string: str, ... :: str): str

let username = "Jasper";
let welcome_message = format("Welcome, %s", username);

print(welcome_message); // Welcome, Jasper

docs.title: printf
docs.text:
Usage:

printf(base_string: str, ... :: str)

let username = "Jasper";
printf("Welcome, %s", username); // Welcome, Jasper

docs.title: str
docs.text:
Usage:

str(obj: any): str

let x = 10;
let s = str(x);

print(type(s)); // 'str'
print(s);       // 10

docs.title: int
docs.text:
Usage:

int(obj: any): int

let s = "10";
let i = int(s);

print(type(i)); // 'int'
print(i);       // 10

docs.title: hasattr
docs.text:
Usage:

hasattr(dict: dictionary, key: str): bool

let a = {
    b: 5
}

print(hasattr(a, "b")); // true

docs.title: getattr
docs.text:
Usage:

getattr(dict: dictionary, key: str): any

let a = {
    b: 5
}

print(getattr(a, "b")); // 5

docs.title: setattr
docs.text:
Usage:

setattr(dict: dictionary, key: str, value: any)

let a = {
    x: 5
};

setattr(a, "y", 10);
print(a.y); // 10

docs.title: loadmodule
docs.text:
Usage:

loadmodule(self, modulePath: str, ... :: any)

let task = loadmodule("@stdlib/task")!

task.wait(5);

//-------------------------------------//

let m = loadmodule("./Module")!
m.a();

//-------------------------------------//

let m = loadmodule("a.tfs");
m.a();

docs.title: cloneobject
docs.text:
Usage:

cloneobject(obj: any): any

let s = "hi!";
let clone = cloneobject(s);
print(clone); // hi!

docs.title: type
docs.text:
Usage:

type(obj: any): "fn" | "int" | "str" | "array" | "dictionary" | "bool"

let s = "hi";
print(type(s)); // str

docs.title: Keywords
docs.text: let, const, fn, elseif, else, for, while, in, true, false, null
